Gallego against Moore If the transcript' of a repord states that tenderednd“A pleain-mriting,” (setting forth 'f'T wFch’¿aid plea the plainnSahy^and issue was join-the this should be general replication to all the pleas; and á repl’eader heSawarded.t0 February 24th, 1813.

The following was delivered by Judge Roane, as the opinion of the court in this case,

“ ín this case, in which the record states, that the appellee tendered “ a plea in writing,” it appears that five several pleas are therein set out and contained j and the record pro» ceeds? immediately subsequent to the last plea, in these words, viz. — “ to which said plea the plaintiff replied gene» ra% » and issue being joined between the parties,” &c.

« Although, under other circumstances, the court might whether this replication and- issue extended to all the p]eas aforesaid, yet the clerk, in introducing them, having considered them as one plea, as aforesaid, we are thereby sufgcient¡y authorized to say, that the replication and issue be» 1 11 r fore mentioned (in the singular number) is co-extensive therewith. Qf course the court, (without deciding upon any other point occurring in the cause,) is of opinion that the judgment of the Superior Court, reversing that qf the County Court, and, in effect, awarding a repleader, is erroneous, and should be reversed, and judgment entered upon the verdict in favour of the appellant.”

|Cr” It was afterwards, during (he same term, discovered that the appellee was dead; whereupon this judgment was set aside, and (he appeal abated.
